solarRevenue.name: Solar profitability calculator
solarRevenue.nasa: The NASA calibration service is not available

infoContent.content: ![](data:image/png;base64,) The interactive **VC Solar App** contains a yield calculator that determines the photovoltaic output on the basis of semantic areas and drawn open spaces and allows the dimensioning and evaluation of a specific solar installation. **Related links:** - https://vc.systems/en/products/vc-solar/

solarSelector.noVCSolar: This surface was not pre-calculated via VC Solar. Use the draw areas option
solarSelector.helpMethod: Select a method for calculating the solar irradiation in the toolbar.
solarSelector.helpMethod2: You can either select an area that has already been calculated or draw a free area. Double-click to end the drawing of an area.
solarSelector.helpMethodArea: To calculate the solar irradiation on a surface, activate the drawing mode in the toolbar and draw an arbitrary surface.
solarSelector.modulesList: Step 2 - Calculate yield of the areas
solarSelector.helpModulesList: All selected or drawn areas are displayed here. For drawn areas, the solar irradiation must be calculated using the (Calculate solar yield) button.
solarSelector.consumptionDataHelp: After you have selected or drawn one or more areas and calculated the solar yield for drawn areas, you can customize your consumption data. The results are adapted directly to your inputs.

help.demand: In this section, you can specify your personal electricity demand. The calculated electricity demand is automatically adjusted to your inputs. However, if you know your exact electricity demand, you can type it directly into the corresponding field.
help.consumption: Depending on your consumption behavior, more electricity from the solar system can be used directly. For example, if you consume more electricity during the day, the proportion of direct consumption will increase. The same applies to storage consumption. You can now specify the proportion of solar power that you consume directly. You have the option of defining the values using predefined consumption profiles.
help.costs: In this section, you can specify your energy costs. To do this, you need to provide the current electricity costs from your supplier. You can also take into account a forecast increase in electricity prices. The average electricity price increase in the period from {startYear} to {endYear} was {increase}%. Further increases are expected in the future.
help.finance: In this section you can choose whether you would like to finance the solar system. You can enter details about the equity capital, the duration and the interest rate. As current interest rates are subject to continuous fluctuations, you will need to carry out your own research.

cotwo.title: Savings
cotwo.text1: A solar system does not emit any CO2 when generating electricity. CO2 is only emitted during the production of solar modules due to the energy required to manufacture them.
cotwo.text2: In your individual case, the CO2 emissions are amortized after a period of:
cotwo.text3: The manufacturing emissions of the solar modules exceed the potential C02 savings
cotwo.text4: The CO2 savings correspond to the calculated comparison with the CO2 emissions that would result from purchasing the same amount of electricity from the German electricity mix (as of %{germanPowerMixYear}).

description.revenue: The income and expense plan compares the annual income and expenses over an assumed lifetime of the PV systems of {lifeTime} years.
description.liquidity: The liquidity trend over {lifeTime} years shows how the initial costs of a solar system are offset over time by savings and income. This reveals when the investment becomes financially profitable.

finance.title: Financing plan
finance.text: In addition to financing via a credit institution, there are other funding options from the state. Further information can be found at KfW

keydata.title: Key data report
keydata.description: The key data report includes a spreadsheet overview of the energy balance (in kWh), the energy cost balance (in â‚¬) and an environmental balance (CO2 in kg). The values given are based on the energy yield of the potential surfaces and the personalized consumption and energy cost data.
keydata.hintText: The total sum results from the entries of all pages in the table.

tooltip.maintenanceCosts: Ongoing costs for maintenance and operation of the solar system. Corresponds to {maintenancePortion}% of the investment costs.
tooltip.gridConsumptionPrice: Costs for the amount of electricity drawn from the public grid.
tooltip.directConsumptionPrice: Costs for the direct consumption portion if no solar system is available and this would have to be drawn from the public grid.
tooltip.storageConsumptionPrice: Costs for the storage consumption share if no solar system is available and this would have to be drawn from the public grid.
tooltip.gridSupplyPrice: Yield for the amount of solar power that is fed into the public grid.
tooltip.liquidity: The cumulative liquidity for each year is calculated by adding the annual cash flow to the previous cumulative amount.

tooltip.solarPowerYield: Total amount of generated solar power.
tooltip.storageLosses: A portion of the energy is lost as conversion losses when storing solar power.
tooltip.directConsumption: Amount of solar power consumed directly during generation.
tooltip.storageConsumption: Amount of solar power used to fill a storage system.
tooltip.gridConsumption: Amount of electricity taken from the public grid to meet energy demand.
tooltip.gridSupply: Amount of surplus solar power fed into the public grid.

tooltip.coTwoSavings: The CO2 savings correspond to the calculated comparison with the CO2 emissions that would result from purchasing the same amount of electricity from the German electricity mix.

colors.hexPattern: Please enter a valid hex color code (e.g., #RRGGBB or #RGB)
